DataElement.preferredName: Gastric Neoplasm Histologic Type WHO Classification of Tumors Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The classification of benign and malignant stomach tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant neoplasm involving the stomach._Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant neoplasm involving the stomach.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant neoplasm involving the stomach.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Gastric Neoplasm WHO Classification of Tumors Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant neoplasm involving the stomach._A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An adenocarcinoma arising from the stomach glandular epithelium. Gastric adenocarcinoma is primarily a disease of older individuals.  It most commonly develops after a long period of atrophic gastritis and is strongly associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. The lack of early symptoms often delays the diagnosis of gastric cancer. The majority of patients present with advanced tumors which have poor rates of curability. Microscopically, two important histologic types of gastric adenocarcinoma are recognized: the intestinal and diffuse type. The overall prognosis of gastric adenocarcinomas is poor, even in patients who receive a "curative" resection (adapted from Sternberg's Surgical Pathology, 3rd ed., 1999).: Not characterized in any other way.

Concepts.definition: An adenocarcinoma arising from the stomach glandular epithelium. Gastric adenocarcinoma is primarily a disease of older individuals.  It most commonly develops after a long period of atrophic gastritis and is strongly associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. The lack of early symptoms often delays the diagnosis of gastric cancer. The majority of patients present with advanced tumors which have poor rates of curability. Microscopically, two important histologic types of gastric adenocarcinoma are recognized: the intestinal and diffuse type. The overall prognosis of gastric adenocarcinomas is poor, even in patients who receive a "curative" resection (adapted from Sternberg's Surgical Pathology, 3rd ed., 1999).
Not characterized in any other way.

PermissibleValues.value: Poorly cohesive carcinoma, including signet ring cell carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A poorly cohesive gastric adenocarcinoma characterized by malignant cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin.

Concepts.definition: A poorly cohesive gastric adenocarcinoma characterized by malignant cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma with more than half of the tumor containing extracellular mucinous pools.

Concepts.definition: A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma with more than half of the tumor containing extracellular mucinous pools.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma characterized by prominent dilated or slit-like tubules.

Concepts.definition: A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma characterized by prominent dilated or slit-like tubules.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma with exophytic growth and elongated finger-like processes lined by cylindrical or cuboidal cells supported by fibrovascular connective tissue cores.

Concepts.definition: A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma with exophytic growth and elongated finger-like processes lined by cylindrical or cuboidal cells supported by fibrovascular connective tissue cores.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
